details.headerOne: Main Entrance to the Sacred Mountain
details.bodyOne:
The Daimon, or "Great Gate," marks the entrance to Mt. Kōya. At a height of 25.1 meters, it is one of the largest temple gates in Japan. The current structure, which dates from the year 1705, is designated as an Important Cultural Property by the Japanese government. Like all temple gates, it represents the boundary between the everyday world and a sacred place beyond. 
Two wooden plaques on either side of the central bay are inscribed with the words, "Day by day [beyond this gate] without fail the miraculous presence of gods and Buddhas is revealed."
details.bodyTwo:
Two wooden statues of Kongō rikishi stand on the left and right sides of the gate. Carved during the mid Edo Era (1603-1868), they are second in size only to those at Nara’s Tōdaiji Temple. These warrior-like figures, also known as Niō, are believed to have followed and protected the Historical Buddha when he traveled throughout India. They have since been adopted into the Japanese Buddhist pantheon and now stand at the entrance to many temples to ward off the enemies of the faith.
The mouth of the guardian on the right is open to represent the sound "ah" and he is accordingly called Agyō. Ungyō, his companion on the left, has his mouth closed as he pronounces the sound "hum."  Together these two syllables create the sound "aum," which is the Sanskrit word for absolute truth or ultimate reality.

details.bodyOne:
Today, almost all visitors to the Danjō Garan enter and exit through a path on the eastern side known as the Shabaramichi, or Snake-Belly Lane. Of course, the more traditional approach to this sacred space would have been through a Chūmon, or Central Gate on the southern side. For most of the past two centuries, however, this entrance was missing, having been destroyed in a devastating fire in 1843. The other buildings lost in this conflagration (which spared only the Saitō, or Western Pagoda) were restored relatively quickly, but the Chūmon was not rebuilt until 2015 as part of the celebrations to commemorate the 1,200th anniversary of the founding of Mt. Kōya. 
The stone footings of the earlier gate can still be seen just in front of the present structure. The current Chūmon rests on similar stone footings. In keeping with the original method of construction, no nails were used, and the pillars rest snugly on their footings with the ends of each meticulously and precisely contoured to the surface of the supporting stones.
details.bodyTwo:
At 16 meters in height and 25 meters in width, the Chūmon is less imposing than the Daimon several hundred meters to the west. But it does feature four statues as opposed to the two housed inside the Great Gate. (It is, in fact, rather rare for gates to have four statues.) These statues are of the Shitennō, or Four Heavenly Kings, who guard each of the cardinal directions.
The pair on the front side of the Chūmon are Tamonten on the right and Jikokuten on the left. Tamonten, or "he who hears the myriad teachings," is depicted with a small golden pagoda in his left hand.  Jikokuten, whose name means "he who upholds the nation," brandishes a sword across his chest. These two statues were carved in 1819 and rescued from the fire of 1843. 
On the other side (facing the Garan) are, from left to right, Kōmokuten, "the wide-eyed one," and Zōjōten, or "he who increases." These statues were completed in 2015 by Matsumoto Myōkei (b. 1945), a sculptor of Buddhist statues belonging to the same school as the unknown artist who carved the other, older two.
In addition to the conventional scroll and brush which he holds in his hands, Kōmokuten is also depicted with a cicada on his breastplate. Similarly, a dragonfly rests in the center of Zōjōten's chest. The cicada is characterized by its loud voice, which spreads out in all directions, and the dragonfly by its ability to fly forward only. Each may be seen as a symbol for the strength and resolution of the deity who bears it.

details.bodyOne:
When Kūkai prepared to establish his monastic community at Mt. Kōya, he was careful to enlist the support of the local deities to whom the mountain belonged. The Shinto shrine standing at the western end of the Danjō Garan is where these gods are now enshrined and worshipped (having been relocated from their original home farther down the mountain).
Called Myōjin-sha or sometimes, more simply, Miyashiro, this shrine comprises three separate sanctuaries (honden). The two on the left in the popular Kasuga-zukuri style house the female goddess Niu-myōjin (a.k.a. Niutsuhime) and her son, the hunter god Kariba-myōjin, respectively. The third, which was added later, is a compound shrine for two sister deities and their many attendants. The current buildings are reconstructions from the year 1594 and are designated as important cultural properties.
details.bodyTwo:
While it may seem strange for a Buddhist temple complex to include a Shinto shrine, the practice is quite widespread in Japan. For Kūkai, in particular, the idea that indigenous deities were incarnations of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas was an important part of his effort to convey the universal nature of esoteric teachings.
The identification of Shinto gods with Buddhas and Bodhisattvas can be seen here at the Myōjin-sha Shrine in the statues of Kariba’s hunting dogs.  Like the Kongō rikishi who guard the temple gates, they are depicted with open and closed mouths as they voice the sacred syllables that represent Dainichi Nyorai in the Diamond and Womb Realms of esoteric Buddhism.

details.bodyOne: Sannō-in, or Temple of the Mountain Kings, is the Buddhist worship hall standing before the Myōjin-sha shrine to the mountain deities. Like the shrine itself, the present-day Sannō-in dates from the year 1594. (The thatched roof is replaced every twenty years.)
details.bodyTwo:
In addition to monthly memorial services, the Sannō-in is the setting for two important and solemn annual rites known as the Rissei and the Misaishōkō.
In the first, priests gather for an all-night session of questions and responses on esoteric teachings. According to legend, the mountain gods became angry when the monks of Mt. Kōya had grown lax in their studies. The Rissei was established to placate their anger and reaffirm Mt. Kōya’s commitment to studies of the Buddhist scriptures. The Misaishōkō is a similar service held over a two-night period for the peace and safekeeping of the nation.

details.bodyOne:
The Rokkaku Kyōzō ("Six-Sided Sutra Repository") is a pagoda-like tower built to house all 3,575 scolls of the "Tripiṭaka," the "Three Baskets" containing the complete body of Buddhist scriptures. 
The original building was established in the twelfth century by an imperial consort named Bifukumon-in (1117-1160) in memory of her husband, Emperor Toba (1103 – 1156). The current structure is a reconstruction dating from the year 1934.
details.headerTwo: Get a Handle on your Sutra Readings
details.bodyTwo:
At the base of the tower are several wooden handles which can be used to rotate the interior shelves of the repository.
It is believed that those who are able to complete three clockwise rotations will receive the spiritual merit equivalent to a complete reading of all the scriptures contained on the shelves.
Feel free to take a turn!

details.bodyOne: Envisioned by Kūkai in his grand design for the Danjō Garan, the original Western Pagoda, or Saitō, was completed in the year 886 by his successor (and nephew), Shinzen (?-891) through the patronage of Emperor Kōkō (830-887). The current 27-meter-tall tower is a reconstruction from 1834.
details.bodyTwo:
The Western Pagoda was conceived as a counterpart to the Great Pagoda at the center of the Danjō Garan. As opposed to the latter, which enshrines Dainich Nyorai as he appears in the Diamond Realm Mandala, the Western Pagoda houses the same cosmic Buddha as depicted in the Womb Realm Mandala. Together, they represent the dual worlds of Shingon Buddhism.
Although one might associate the Western Pagoda with the Eastern Pagoda, or Tōtō, at the other end of the Garan, the latter was an addition from the 12th century and not part of Kūkai's original conception.

details.bodyOne:
Across from the Kondō and just to the west of the Great Pagoda we find the Miedō, or Hall of the Blessed Image.  While closed to the public (for all but one day a year) and dedicated to housing a shrouded image, its elegant proportions, gracefully curved roof and lantern-lined eaves, make the exterior of the Miedō a favorite of photographers throughout the four seasons. 
The current structure was built in 1848 at a location where Kūkai’s private Buddhist shrine originally stood.  A careful inspection of the railing at south-east corner of the Miedō shows the scars of the 1926 fire that destroyed the nearby Kondō. To prevent the Miedō from a similar fate, a covered trough encircles the building. Within, are nozzles ready to spray the structure with water in case of fire.
details.bodyTwo:
The Blessed Image from which the Miedō takes its name is a portrait of Kūkai. It is believed to be the work of Prince Shinnyo (799 – 865?), the son of an emperor and devoted Kūkai follower, who painted it six days before the holy man left this world. 
The image is so sacred that it can only be viewed by priests of the highest rank and then only once in a lifetime. While the original portrait is concealed behind a ceremonial cloth, two- and three-dimensional copies of it, showing Kūkai sitting cross-legged in a chair with his ritual sceptre (vajra) in hand, can be seen throughout Mt. Kōya.

details.bodyOne: This small temple is named after the bodhisattva Cundī (Juntei or Jundei, in Japanese) whose image it enshrines. Also known the Mother of Many Buddhas, this female deity is a central object of reverence in the ordination rites to the Buddhist priesthood. According to legend, the actual image was made for this purpose by Kūkai himself. It was originally housed in the monastery refectory and later moved here after the Junteidō was completed sometime before the year 973. The present structure, one of numerous reconstructions, dates from the year 1883.
details.bodyTwo: Each year on July 1, the Junteidō is the setting for the Juntei Dhāraṇī Assembly, an important religious service for the repentance of sins.

details.bodyOne: When a severe drought afflicted Japan in the year 1199, Retired Emperor Gotoba (1180-1239) commissioned the head priest of Kyoto’s Tōji Temple to conduct prayers for rain. In gratitude for the success of these services, Gotoba ordered the construction of the Kujakudō at Mt. Kōya. The current building is a reconstruction from 1983, dedicated as part of the services in commemoration of the 1150th anniversary of Kūkai’s entrance into perpetual meditation.
details.bodyTwo:
Kujaku is the Japanese name for Mahāmāyūrī, a female Wisdom King whose name means Great Peafowl (so, more correctly, "peahen"). An apotheosis of a bird that is said to eat poisonous snakes, Kujaku is believed to offer divine protection of the nation against various calamities. (Is it irreverent to note that she was not able to spare even her own temple from the many fires that have plagued Mt. Kōya over the centuries?) 
A statue of Kujaku purportedly carved by the artist Kaikei (fl. Kamakura Era) was moved from the Kujakudō and is now on display at the nearby Reihōkan Museum. She is seated on a lotus throne borne on the back of a peacock. As in customary depictions of Kujaku, her face lacks the fierce expression typically seen in representations of the other Wisdom Kings.

details.bodyOne:
Included on Kūkai’s wish list for his monastery and finally completed during the tenure of his successor, Shinzen (d. 891), is the Bell of the Great Pagoda. Descendant of previous structures that were destroyed by fire, the current bell tower is made of reinforced concrete. The bronze bell itself was cast in the year 1547. At 2.21 meters in diameter, it is the fourth largest temple bell in Japan earning it the nickname "Kōya Shirō" – a name traditionally given to a family’s fourth son.
Five times a day, a priest mounts the platform to swing the heavy suspended beam that serves as the bell’s clapper. The momentum required to strike the bell to produce the desired sound can lift the priest off his feet. The movements provide a graceful visual accompaniment to the low, loud tolling of the bell.
details.headerTwo: A Measurement of Time / An Expression of Impermanence
details.bodyTwo: Visitors who happen to be at the Danjō Garan at 4 am, 1 pm, 6 pm (5 pm during fall and winter), 9 pm or 11 pm can listen for the three different parts that make up the sound of a bell: the initial impact (or atari), the reverberation (oshi) and the prolonged dissipation (okuri). The combined effect is meant to remind us of the impermanence of existence, which, like the sound of the bell, can overwhelm us with a sense of its presence only to vanish into silence.

details.bodyOne: The Danjō Garan is where the earliest places of worship were built on Mt Kōya after its founding in the year 817 by the priest Kūkai. Dominated by the imposing central tower known as the Konpon Daitō, the complex extends roughly 350 meters from east to west and is made up of around twenty structures including a massive hall, several sanctuaries, pagodas and shrines.  While none of the original buildings survives, many of their reconstructions date back centuries.
details.bodyTwo: As it has for more than a millennium, the Danjō Garan serves as the primary center for the most important ceremonies and rites of Shingon, or Esoteric, Buddhism. Visitors will find themselves in the company of devoted members of the faith as they worship at these sacred sites. It is not uncommon to see large groups of priests making their rounds to pray before the various holy places.

details.bodyOne:
The Danjō Garan and, indeed, all of Mt. Kōya are dominated by the 48-meter-tall, vermillion-colored tower that gives physical presence to the central idea that pervades Shingon Buddhist belief. Known as the Konpon Daitō, or “Great Tower of the Fundamental [Principle],” the original building was conceived by Kūkai as the central locus of ritual concentration and meditation. It was completed in 887 by his successor and nephew, Shinzen (d. 891).
Records indicate that the tower has been rebuilt no fewer than five times since the original was destroyed by a lightning strike in 994. The present structure, which is made of reinforced concrete, was rededicated in 1937.
The tower enshrines a large golden image of Dainichi Nyorai (Mahāvairocana), the Great Sun Buddha and principal object of worship within Esoteric Buddhism.  Dainichi appears as he does in the Womb Realm Mandala with his hands in the samādhi (or dhyāni) mudrā of meditation. But he is surrounded by statues of four Buddhas and sixteen columns of Bodhisattvas as they are arranged in the Diamond Realm Mandala. Konpon Daitō is, thus, not only a three-dimensional mandala; it is a synthesis of these two worlds and a manifest statement of their ultimate non-duality.
details.bodyTwo:
In Buddhist architecture, two types of tower can be identified. One is the stupa which evolved in India from memorial monuments housing relics of the historical Buddha and other holy men. The other is the pagoda, an East Asian variant, which, like stupa is meant to communicate the presence of the Buddha. Typically, the center of the pagoda symbolizes the absolute truth at the center of the universe. Here, at Mt. Kōya that space is occupied by the Great Sun Buddha, the embodiment of that truth.
The Konpon Daitō is an example of a tahōtō, or "pagoda of myriad treasures," which is distinctive of Shingon, or Esoteric, Buddhist architecture. The tower built here at Mt. Kōya under Kūkai’s instructions is the first such tower in Japan. The two-tier structure and its incorporation of circular and spherical forms is reminiscent of Indian stupa design (and perhaps why it is sometimes called the "Great Stupa"). The five vertical sections of the tower, from base to spire, conform to Esoteric cosmology with each section representing one of the Five Sacred Elements: Earth, Water, Fire, Wind and Emptiness.

details.bodyOne:
The Kondō, or “Golden Hall,” was one of the earliest buildings established at Mt. Kōya by its founder, Kūkai. Originally, known as the Kōdō, or “Lecture Hall,” it remains the setting for most of the important religious services held throughout the year at Mt. Kōya. The term “Golden Hall,” which it shares with the main halls of other early Buddhist temples (Nara’s Hōryūji and Tōshōdaiji temples, for example), is thought to stem from either the gilt used as part of the interior ornamentation or perhaps the golden color of the Buddhist image venerated within.
The central object of worship inside the Golden Hall of Mt. Kōya is Ashuku Nyorai (Skt: Akshobhya) whose image is located behind the closed doors of a black cabinet behind the central dais. In Esoteric Buddhism, this Buddha is identified with Yakushi Nyorai (Skt: Bhaisajyaguru), the Buddha of Medicine and Healing. While his image is hidden (revealed only once, during the celebrations of 1,200th-anniversary of the founding of Mt. Kōya), we can see six companion deities in the bays to the left and right. They are Kokūzō Bosatsu, Gōzanze Myō'ō, and Kongō-ō; and Kongōsatta, Fudō Myō'ō, and Fugen Bosatsu, respectively.
Facing each other from the left and right sides of the large central area (known as the naijin) are the two mandala central to Shingon Buddhist faith and practice. On the left (or western) side is the Diamond Realm Mandala; on the right (or eastern) side is the Womb Realm Mandala. The latter is sometimes called the “Blood Mandala” in reference to a legend in which Taira no Kiyomori (1118 – 1181) is said to have used blood from his own forehead to color part of the diadem of the Great Sun Buddha.
The actual mandala are housed at the nearby Reihōkan Museum as smoke from incense used at the Kondō was judged to be harmful to these important treasures.
details.bodyTwo:
Like almost all of the major buildings of Mt. Kōya’s Danjō Garan, the Golden Hall is one in a succession of reconstructions after its predecessor had been destroyed by fire. The current structure dates from 1932; it is the sixth Kondō to have stood on the present and original site. The previous Golden Hall burned to the ground in a fire in the early hours of December 26, 1926, between memorial services for the Taishō Emperor Yoshihito, who had died the day before.
Despite frantic efforts to save them, most of the precious objects inside the Kondō were reduced to ashes.
The sculptures used to replace the lost images of Ashuku and his six companions were carved by the artist Takamura Kōun (1865 – 1934) who was 75 years old when he began the five-year project to complete the new statues. Each day he worked, Takamura underwent ritual purification and maintained a strict fast. While the centerpiece of his work is hidden from view, we can certainly admire the religious piety and devotion of the artist.

details.headerOne: Hall of the Immovable Wisdom King
details.bodyOne:
The original Fudōdō, or Hall of the Immovable One, was built by the holy man Gyōshō (1130 – 1217) at the behest of Princess Hachijo, a daughter of Emperor Toba. The current building, which is one of the oldest at Mt. Kōya, is from the second half of the 14th century.
Among its unique features are the different styles with which its four corners were designed, a consequence of having been constructed by four different builders. Also, unlike most temples, Fudōdō has more of a residential appearance.
While believed to have originally housed the Buddha Amida Nyorai (Amitābha), it was later dedicated to and named for Acala, the Immovable Wisdom King. Fudō Myō'ō, as he is known in Japanese, is a fierce, warrior-like deity highly revered in Shingon as a manifestation of Dainichi Nyorai. Despite his rather frightening appearance, he is popular among the faithful for his determination to protect Buddhism from its enemies.
Statues of Fudō Myō'ō as well as his eight attendants, which were once housed in this hall, are national treasures and are prominently displayed in a special room at the nearby Reihōkan Museum. The figures of the eight attendants are the work of the master sculptor Unkei (d. 1223).
details.bodyTwo: With one exception, all the buildings of the Danjō Garan face south, in accordance with the traditional Buddhist arrangement for such buildings. The only one that does not is the Fudōdō. This is because the original temple was situated in a small valley beyond the hill behind the Garan. It was moved to its present location in 1908.

details.headerOne: At the Foot of the Buddha
details.bodyOne: In Buddhism, the lotus symbolizes the true nature of being which, like the flower emerging out of muddy waters, remains unsullied by the corruption of the world. For this reason, they are utilized as the seat upon which a Buddha is enthroned. Additionally, the imagery of the lotus is mirrored at Mt. Kōya by the eight surrounding peaks which call to mind the eight petals of the lotus blossom. Here at the Danjō Garan, the lotuses bloom at the feet of the celestial Buddha Dainichi Nyorai, whose name in Japanese means "Great Sun."
details.bodyTwo: Temple ponds are also often associated with the wondrous powers of dragons. The Chinese-style bridge that crosses the lotus pond at the Danjō Garan leads to a small shrine dedicated to "Zennyo-ryū-ō," the Benevolent Dragon Queen who, according to legend, aided Kūkai in his prayers to end a severe drought in the year 824.

details.headerOne: Hall of the Love-Stained Wisdom King
details.bodyOne: The Aizendō, or Hall of Aizen, was constructed under an imperial order from Emperor Godaigo (1288 – 1339) in 1334. The current structure is a reconstruction from 1848. The main object of worship is an image of Aizen Myō'ō that was reportedly carved to the same proportions as Godaigo himself. Aizen Myō'ō is the Japanese name for Rāgarāja, a Hindu deity adopted into the Buddhist pantheon as one of many so-called Wisdom Kings. His name means Love-Stained Wisdom King, and he is thought to help people transform their lustful impulses into spiritual awakening.
details.headerTwo: A Wish for Peace in Troubled Times
details.bodyTwo: It was Godaigo's wish to establish the Aizendō for the tranquility of the nation and the safety of the imperial family. Godaigo is best remembered for overthrowing the civilian military government of the Kamakura shoguns. The brief, three-year period from 1333 to 1336 in which real political power was restored to the emperors is known as the Kenmu Restoration. When Godaigo was himself overthrown by the Ashikaga's, he fled to the Yoshino region and established a rival Southern Court. For the next fifty years, Japan had two emperors. Godaigo's wish for tranquility and safety must be seen in light of this turbulent historical context.

details.bodyOne:
The building now known as the Dai’edō, or Great Gathering Hall, was originally erected in 1175 at the wishes of Imperial Princess Itsutsusai-in (1145-1208) for the memory and salvation of her father, Emperor Toba (1103–1156). At the time it was called Rengejō-in and was located about a kilometer to the east of its current location. As the venue for marathon sutra reading services, which could last for days, it was later moved to the Danjō Garan.
The move to its current location was carried out by the famous poet-priest Saigyō (1112-1190), who served, at the time, as the priest in charge of fund raising (kanjin) for Rengejō-in.
The current building, a reconstruction from 1848, is still used for large memorial services and houses images of the Buddha Amida Nyorai along with the bodhisattvas Daiseishi and Kannon.
details.bodyTwo:
The Dai’edo is not the only building at Mt. Kōya that was built for the salvation Retired Emperor Toba. The nearby Rokkaku-kyōzō, or Six-Sided Sutra Repository, was built in his memory by his wife, Empress Bifukumon-in (1117–1160), who was also the mother of the princess patron of the Dai’edo.
Toba, his grandfather Emperor Shirakawa (1053-1129) and his son Go-Shirakawa (1127–1192), who all became Buddhist priests after their abdications, were themselves generous patrons of Mt. Kōya. Their donations of estates for the maintenance of the monastery as well as their official visits played an important role in the expansion of Mt. Kōya and its popularization as a Buddhist Pure Land.

details.bodyOne:
The Tōtō, or Eastern Pagoda, was originally built in 1127 by a priest from Daigo-ji’s Sambō-in Temple in Kyoto at the request of Retired Emperor Shirakawa (1053-1129). The main object of worship is an image of the Buddha Sonshōbutchō (Vikiraṇoṣṇīṣa) which was carved to the same physical proportions as Shirakawa. This Buddha is flanked by images of the Wisdom Kings Fudō and Gōzanze Myō'ō. Like many of the holy images enshrined in the halls and towers of the Garan, these statues are not open to the public.
The current building is a reconstruction from the year 1984, rebuilt 140 years after the previous tower was destroyed in a large conflagration that destroyed almost all of the buildings of the Danjō Garan.
details.bodyTwo:
Today, the Eastern Pagoda stands in an apparent complementary relationship to the Saitō, or Western Pagoda at the other end of the Garan. This, however, was not the original concept, as Kūkai intended the Saitō to form a pair with the Daitō, or Great Pagoda.
Notwithstanding the original conception, today, the Eastern and Western Pagodas naturally invite comparison. As the only surviving structure from the devastating fire of 1843, and tucked away in a tree lined corner of the Garan, the Saitō bears a weathered and venerable aspect and provides a rich contrast with the brighter, freshly painted exterior of the Tōtō.

details.headerOne: For the Preservation and Display of Mt. Kōya's Sacred Treasures
details.bodyOne:
Visitors to Mt. Kōya, or to many other religious sites in Japan, are sometimes disappointed to find that many buildings cannot be entered or that the treasures inside are often hidden from view. Even more sadly, certain priceless objects have been lost to various disasters that have occurred over the centuries.
Located across the street and a bit to the east of the Lotus Pond of the Danjō Garan, the Reihōkan, or Museum of Sacred Treasures, offers visitors a chance to view many of the cultural treasures belonging to the various temples and halls of Mt. Kōya.
details.bodyTwo:
The original wing of the museum, established in 1921, and a newer annex, added in 1998, present permanent and special exhibitions of sculptures, paintings, mandala, ritual implements, and texts — many of which have been designated as National Treasures or Important Cultural Properties by the Japanese government.
Not to be missed are the large paintings entitled "Amida's Descent to Welcome the Faithful into Paradise" and "The Reclining Buddha;" as well as sculptures of "The Eight Attendants of Fudō Myō'ō" and a carved triptych known as the "Shrine of the Buddhist Deities." Two replicas of the enormous Diamond Realm and Womb Realm Mandala are also quite impressive.
Special exhibits often include examples of Kūkai's handwriting, offering a chance to see why, among other remarkable accomplishments, he is also regarded as one of Japan's greatest calligraphers.

details.headerOne: The Main Headquarters of the Shingon Sect
details.bodyOne:
Kongōbuji, or "Temple of the Diamond Peak," is the name that the founder of Mt. Kōya gave to his entire monastic center. Today, however, it refers more specifically to the sprawling complex of buildings that serve as the administrative headquarters for more than 3,600 Shingon temples throughout Japan. 
The temple that we see today dates back to the late 16th century when the famous feudal lord Toyotomi Hideyoshi established a temple called Seigan-ji in memory of his mother. In the year 1869, this temple merged with Kōzan-ji Temple to become the present-day Kongōbuji.
The temple spreads out over 160,000 square meters and comprises a series of interconnected wings and galleries. These include the living quarters of the Abbot and other priests, formal reception rooms, a scripture library, meditation halls, lecture halls and a large working kitchen for monastery residents. Many rooms feature decorative sliding doors painted by Kanō Tan'yū, one of the most famous Edo-Era painters. Among the interior gradens and courtyards, is Japan's largest rock garden.
details.bodyTwo: In addition to exploring the decorative rooms and historic points of interest, visitors to Kongōbuji are invited to enjoy tea and refreshments while listening to a sermon in the the large Shin-Betsuden (New Annex). Visitors can also participate in the Shingon practice of ajikan meditation.

details.bodyOne:
There are two prominent bell towers at Mt. Kōya. One is the bell placed at Kūkai’s directions in the Danjō Garan before the Great Pagoda. The other is the “Six O’Clock Bell,” which is mounted on a large stone base located to the west of the entrance to Kongō-buji Temple. The original bell and tower were erected in the year 1618 by the feudal lord Fukushima Masanori (1561 – 1624) in memory of his mother. The bell was later recast by Masanori’s son Masatoshi (1601–1637). 
Temple bells typically bear inscriptions written entirely with Chinese characters; this one is unusual for using a mix of kanji and Japanese kana.
The bell tolls nine times a day beginning at 6:00 am and at every even numbered hour until 10:00 pm. The present-day bell tower is a reconstruction from the year 1835.
details.bodyTwo: Interestingly, Fukushima Masanori, the patron responsible for the Six O’Clock Bell, was one of Toyotomi Hideyoshi’s loyal generals who was dispatched to Mt Kōya with orders that Hideyoshi’s nephew, Hidetsugu (b. 1568) be put to death for an alleged plot to overthrow his uncle. Hidetsugu along with three young companions committed ritual suicide in July of 1595 in the Yanagi-no-ma or Willow Room inside Kongō-buji Temple

details.bodyOne: The "Garden of the Guardian Dragons" (Banryū-tei) is the largest garden of its kind in Japan featuring 140 large rocks emerging from a bed of raked white pebbles. The rocks represent a male and a female dragon rising from a sea of clouds to protect the "Inner Hall" (Okuden). This building, which offers the best view of the garden, is across the way from the balustraded walkway used by visitors. Unfortunately, it is closed to the general public except on special occasions.
details.headerTwo: Commemorating the Passage of the Master
details.bodyTwo: The garden, along with the nearby "Shin-Betsuden," was completed in 1984 as part of the 1150th anniversary of Kūkai’s entrance into perpetual meditation. The large rocks representing the protector dragons were brought to Mt. Kōya from the island of Shikoku, where Kūkai was born.

details.bodyOne:
Nyonindō is a reminder of the times in the past when women were prohibited from entering the sacred precincts of Mt. Kōya, where their presence was thought to have distracted the priests from their prayers and meditations. 
Kūkai, the founder of the monastic complex here, famously forbade even his own mother from visiting. Other women who tried to enter or communicate with male relatives living on the mountain were rebuffed with the harsh reminder that their loved ones were "dead to them."
In 1873, the Japanese government officially prohibited temples from banning women. However, here at Mt. Kōya, the practice continued until 1916.
details.bodyTwo:
The prohibition (known as "nyonin-kinzei") did not stop women of faith from trying to get as close as possible to the resting place of Kōbō-daishi and the temple complex he had established. Despite the difficulties of the journey, many women made their way to the one of the seven entrances to Mt. Kōya in the hope of getting a glimpse of the rooftops of the holy shrines within. 
Overnight lodging for these women was provided by seven "nyonindō," or "women's halls," located at each of the gates to the monastery. The small temple that stands here today dates from the year 1871 and is the only remaining women's hall.

details.bodyOne:
While most of Mt. Kōya’s monuments to famous historic figures are found within the huge cemetery of Oku-no-in, a notable exception is the family mausoleum of the Tokugawas, who ruled Japan from 1603 to 1867.
The two ornate shrines standing side-by-side within the fenced enclosure were built in 1643 by the third Tokugawa Shōgun, Iemitsu (1604-1651), for his father Hidetada (1579-1632) and his grandfather Ieyasu (1543-1616). A third building to house the mortuary tablets of other members of the so-called Three Houses of the Tokugawa once stood at the eastern edge of the precincts. It was lost to fire in 1888.
details.bodyTwo: One Tokugawa presumably not included among those memorialized here was was Iemitsu’s younger brother, Tadanaga (1605-1633). At the age of 28, Tadanaga was accused of misconduct and ordered by his brother to commit ritual suicide. Today, the largest gorintō monument at Oku-no-in is one that Tadanaga built in memory of his mother. It is named the Monument of the Major Councilor of Suruga, which was Tadanaga’s title before his death.

details.bodyOne:
Located a short walk to the north above Mt. Kōya’s main road is Kongō Sammai-in Temple, which features Mt. Kōya’s oldest surviving building, a pagoda built in the year 1223.
The temple itself was established at the behest of Hōjō Masako (1156–1225) for the salvation of her husband Minamoto no Yoritomo (1147 -1199) and her son Sanetomo (1192-1219), who had died at the age of 26. As the wife of the first and mother of the second and third shoguns of the Kamakura Era (1185-1333), Masako was one of the most powerful women in Japanese history and is known at the "Nun Shogun."
details.bodyTwo:
The pagoda is a tahōtō (pagoda of myriad treasures) and, as Japan’s second oldest surviving building of this type, an excellent example of Kamakura-Era architecture. It is listed as a National treasure by the Japanese government.
The fifteen-meter-tall tower enshrines statues of the Five Wisdom Tathāgatas (Gochi Nyorai). If the traditional attribution of these statues to Unkei is correct, they would be among the last works of this master sculptor.

details.bodyOne:
The main object worship of Karukaya Hall is Indō Jizō, who, as his name suggests, leads people to paradise after their death. However, the temple is much more famous for the moving story of a desperate boy named Ishidōmaru and his search for his father.
According to the tale, Ishidōmaru’s father became disillusioned by the hostility between his wife and his mistress (imagine that!), so he decided to abandon the world by taking holy orders at Mt. Kōya. After falling on hard times, Ishidōmaru and his mother journeyed to Mt. Kōya to seek him out. Since women were not permitted on the holy mountain, Ishidōmaru made the climb alone. On his way, he met a kind priest named Karukaya Dōshin who informed the boy that the father he was looking for had died. He was even able to point to the stone that marked his grave.
The disappointed Ishidōmaru returned to the foot of the mountain only to discover that his mother had died in his absence. The now orphaned Ishidōmaru had no choice but to return to the mountain where he shaved his head and took Buddhist vows, placing himself under the care and guidance of the priest he had met earlier.
For the rest of their lives Ishidōmaru and Karukaya Dōshin devoted themselves to worship and ascetic practices. In all that time, the older priest never revealed to the boy that he was, in fact, his real father.
details.bodyTwo: The full story, which has been retold in various forms including kabuki plays and manga comic books, is presented in illustrated panels along an inner gallery of the present-day Karukayadō, Also on display are three statues called the Oyako Jizō (Parents with Child Jizō). These three figures are (all too conveniently) said to have been carved by Ishidōmaru and his father.

details.headerOne: The Approach to the Inner Sanctuary
details.bodyOne:
A clever promotional appeal for Mt Kōya once invited visitors to "spend a day where thousands have chosen to spend eternity." The slogan was an obvious reference to the vast necropolis to the east of the mountain's main temple complex.
Known as Oku-no-in, it is the largest cemetery in Japan and — along with the Danjō Garan — one of the two most sacred areas of Mt. Kōya. Here, beneath a canopy of massive cryptomeria trees, more than 200,000 stone monuments stand alongside a two-kilometer stone path leading to the mausoleum of Kūkai, the eighth patriarch of Shingon Buddhism and the founder of Mt. Kōya.  Many of these monuments are centuries old, and many are dedicated to the memory of some of the most famous and powerful people in Japanese history.
details.bodyTwo:
Oku-no-in means Inner Sanctuary and refers to the resting place, or gobyō, of Kūkai.  While typically glossed as mausoleum or tomb, this translation is, for the faithful, somewhat imprecise.
Kūkai left this world in 835 at the age of 62. However, his followers believe that he did not die in the ordinary sense. Instead, he is thought to have entered a state of deep meditation (nyūjō) in which both breathing and the beating of the heart are suspended. His seated body, with hands positioned in the mudra for Dainichi Nyorai, is enshrined within the Inner Sanctuary. 
Over the centuries, thousands of individuals have chosen to have their own memorials erected nearby to wait in attendance with Kūkai until the time when the future Buddha appears on earth to lead humanity to salvation.

details.headerOne: For the Care and Protection of the Unborn
details.bodyOne:
Just beyond the bridge marking the entrance to the Oku-no-in Sandō, standing on the left side of the path, are three tall, black statues. These are the Sanhei Mizuko Jizō. The word "mizuko" literally means water child, and refers to any baby whose healthy birth was prevented by either miscarriage, stillbirth or abortion. Signifying its role in the spiritual care and protection of these children, each of the Sanhei Mizuko Jizō holds a golden fetus in its left hand. Two small infants cling to the statues on the left.
The jizō on the extreme left lacks the halo seen on the other two and has a distinctly more female appearance. Though formally identified as the Jizō of Peace, this bodhisattva is popularly referred to as "Maria-sama," due to a presumed resemblance to the mother of Jesus.
details.bodyTwo: Memorial services for unborn children are carried out at temples throughout Japan. Known as mizuko kuyō, these rites are intended to provide comfort and consolation for the grief and possible guilt of the parents of the unborn. While some people say that the services are also meant to avert retribution from potentially vengeful spirits, a Shingon website assures us that this is not the case. Unborn children are strangers to the corruption of our world and, therefore, incapable of anger or vengeance, the website reminds us.

details.bodyOne:
Along a lesser used side path just beyond the Ichi-no-Hashi Bridge, is one of the more unexpected features at Oku-no-in. It is a replica of a 2.7-meter-tall monument originally erected in China in the year 781. The nine Chinese characters at the top give the name of the monument as "The Memorial to the Propagation in China of the Luminous Religion of Daqin." The inscription below (in Chinese and Syriac) records the arrival of a man name Alopen 阿羅本 in the capital of Chang’an in the year 635.
So who was Alopen? Where is Daqin? What faith is meant by the “Luminous Religion”? And, finally, why is there a full-sized copy of this monument here at Mt. Kōya?
A clue to the answers appears just above its name, where we can clearly see a Christian cross within the triangular space between the two dragons. Alopen, as is known from this monument and this monument alone, seems to have been the first Christian missionary to China. He is believed to have been of Syrian origin and a member of the Church of the East, a branch of Christianity which is sometimes identified with the Nestorians. The place name Daqin, mentioned in the name of the stele, was used by the Chinese to refer variously to either the Roman or Byzantine empires.
The original monument, which was re-discovered in 1625 after having been buried for more than seven centuries, is a testament to the recognition of Christianity by the second emperor of the Tang Dynasty.
details.bodyTwo:
The establishment of a replica of this monument here at Mt. Kōya is the work of an English woman named Elizabeth Anna Gordon (1851–1925). A devout Christian, Gordon spent most of the last 18 years of her life in Japan studying Buddhism and collecting various works of art. It was one of her beliefs that Buddhism and Christianity were fundamentally related. The “Stele of the Luminous Religion” was proof that Christianity was known in Chang’an at the time that Kūkai lived there.  Since it is likely that he would have been aware of Christianity, the development of Kūkai’s religious thought and the doctrine of “True Speech” (i.e. "Shingon") may have been influenced by its teachings.
Under Gordon’s patronage, this replica was created and placed at Oku-no-in in 1911. This was still a few years before women were allowed on the mountain, so Mrs. Gordon may not have beenthere to see its dedication. Her ashes, however, are buried nearby.

details.bodyOne: Kazutori Jizō stands alongside Oku-no-in Sandō and — as his name suggests — counts the number of times each individual passes by on his or her way to to the mausoleum of Kūkai. It is said that he will appear on our judgment day and appeal to Enma, the god of the underworld, asking that the number of our sins be reduced by the number of times we have visited this place.
details.bodyTwo: The faded story on the wooden panel tells us that the stone statue of this jizō was once broken into several pieces and buried in the ground. In the 17th century, a lacquerware master from Osaka had a vision in a dream telling him where to find the lost statue. The man, whose name was Tazaemon, unearthed the statue, restored it and had it placed where we see it today.

details.bodyOne: The name given on this monument is Tada no Mitsunaka, but he is better known as Minamoto no Mitsunaka (912-997), using the name of the powerful clan that would eventually rule Japan at the beginning of the Kamakura Era (1185-1333). While the greatest exploits of this clan were carried out by Mitsunaka’s sons, grandsons and great-grandsons, his tombstone is of note for being the oldest dated gorintō monument at Oku-no-in (997).
details.bodyTwo:
The short answer is "no."
Most of the monuments to the dead at Oku-no-in are commonly identified with the Japanese word, "haka," which is translated as either "grave," or "tomb." But it is important to clarify that the Japanese sense of the word is broader in meaning and includes monuments to the spirit of the deceased.
More strictly speaking, the vast majority of these monuments are kuyōtō 供養塔 which – though they may contain cremated ashes or relics of hair and bone – may best be thought of as resting places for the spirit rather than for the physical remains of the dead.
For this reason, an individual may sometimes have multiple "tombs." Mitsunaka offers a case in point: there are no fewer than seven locations in Japan identified as his "haka."

details.headerOne: Graves of Takeda Shingen and Son Katsuyori
details.bodyOne:
The stone fence of this monument encloses two gorintō towers. The one on the left is for Takeda Shingen (1521–1573), who was one of the most powerful and skilled warlords of the Sengoku, or Warring States, Era (1467-1615). Known as the "Tiger of Kai," in reference to his home province (present-day Yamanashi Prefecture), Shingen is best remembered for a series of indecisive battles against his arch-rival Uesugi Kenshin (1530-1578) who is said to have wept when he learned of Shingen’s death. Their fabled rivalry is a favorite among students of Japanese history. Kenshin’s above-ground mausoleum is now located at Oku-no-in only a short distance away.
The  gorintō on the right is for Takeda’s son Katsuyori (1542-1582) who, after succeeding his father, was defeated by the allied forces of Oda Nobunaga and Tokugawa Ieyasu. Katsuyori’s monument is engraved with the date of his suicide by ritual disembowelment (seppuku).
details.bodyTwo: A  nearby sign directs our attention to a small rock encircled by a small stone fence. This is called the "Daishi-no-Koshikake-ishi," or the Stone Seat of the Great Master. Apparently, the founder of Mt. Kōya once sat here.

details.bodyOne:
Uesugi Kenshin (1530-1578) was one of the most famous and revered daimyō of Japan's Sengoku, or "Warring States," Era (1467-1615).
Uesugi visited Mt. Kōya in 1574, three years before his death.　It was at that time that he received the name Kenshin.
details.bodyTwo: Unlike most of the monuments to the dead at Oku-no-in, Kenshin’s spirit is enshrined in an above-ground wooden building, which – based on its features – is believed to date from the beginning of the Edo Era. Inside, there is an altar with two stone memorial tablets, one for Kenshin and the other for his adopted son, Kagekatsu (1556-1623). Records suggest that a separate mausoleum for Kagekatsu may have stood beside that of Kenshin’s until they were eventually merged in the mid 19th century.

details.bodyOne:
The monument to Akechi Mitsuhide (1528–1582) is situated a few steps off the pathway to the Inner Sanctuary. While it is one of many monuments to famous military figures at Oku-no-in, this one is of particular fascination because of a purported curse that causes a large crack to appear on one of its stones despite several attempts to replace and repair it.
Mitsuhide served as one of Oda Nobunaga’s (1534 –1582 ) most important generals during his campaign to unify Japan in the 16th century. He was instrumental in Nobunaga’s siege of the Tendai monastery of Mt. Hiei in 1571 – a brutal affair that resulted in the slaughter of 20,000 people, including priests, women and children.
In 1582, Mitsuhide turned against his former lord and carried out the attack on Kyoto's Honnoji Temple that forced Nobunaga to commit ritual suicide. Mitsuhide himself was then pursued and killed by Toyotomi Hideyoshi (1536 -1598) a month later.
details.bodyTwo: Despite having rid Japan of the "Devil King" Nobunaga, Mitsuhide’s reputation as his lord's treacherous assassin looms large in the popular imagination of the Japanese. For this reason, perhaps, his name appears in blood-red letters on his tombstone. The section that consistently cracks is the spherical stone representing water.  This is taken as indubitable proof that his monument is, indeed, cursed by the ghost of Nobunaga. As the temple where he was trapped was engulfed by flames, what else would Nobunaga have cried out for if not water?

details.bodyOne: Just beyond the Naka-no-Hashi Bridge, we find one of the many mysteries of Mt. Kōya — a sweating statue of the bodhisattva Jizō. Condensation on the metal statue has been interpreted by the faithful as sweat caused as Jizō, in his compassion, assumes the suffering of all people.
details.headerTwo: A Well with a Chilling Legend
details.bodyTwo: To the right of the Sweating Jizō is the Sugatami-ido, or Shape-Reflecting Well. According to an early legend, the miraculous healing powers of this well were revealed by Kūkai to a sick man in a dream. For this reason the well was known as the Kusuri-i (the Medicinal Well). A more recent tradition, popularized in the Edo Era, claims that anyone who peers into the well and fails to see his or her reflection will die within three years. (A similar curse is associated with the nearby section of the Oku-no-in Sandō. It is said that anyone who stumbles and falls on any of the 42 steps known as the Kakuban Slope will also die within three years.)

details.headerOne: Poem by the Great Master of the Haiku
details.bodyOne:
Throughout Mt. Kōya there are more than 120 stone monuments engraved with poems by well-known poets. Arguably the best known of these poets (both in and outside Japan) is the great master of the 17-syllable haiku, Matsuo Bashō (1605-1633).  Although his Oku-no-hosomichi (Narrow Road to the Deep North; 1689) is his most famous travel account,  Bashō recorded poems and reflections on other journeys as well. One of these is Oi no kobumi (Jottings from my Knapsack; 1709), which chronicles a visit made to this area in the year 1687. 
The poem composed while visiting Oku-no-in reads: 
chichi haha no / shikiri ni koishi / kiji no koe 
("with intense longing for father and mother – the voice of a pheasant")
The English translation fails to convey the effect created by the consonantal k and vocalic i sounds, which combine in the original Japanese to evoke the sorrowful cries of the pheasant .
details.bodyTwo: Not to be missed is a stone statue of Jizō located almost directly across the main path from the Bashō poem. Known as the O-Keshō or Rouged Jizō, it is a favorite among visitors to Mt. Kōya. It is said that one can gain spiritual merit by applying make-up to its face. (Usually there are some old lipsticks leaning against the back for any would-be cosmological cosmetologists.)

details.bodyOne:
This river, now spanned by the Gobyō Bridge, marks the entrance to the most sacred area of Mt. Kōya. Its name can be rendered as either Jewel or Spirit River (the Japanese word "tama" being a homophone for both).
Thin wooden tablets are sometimes placed in the river to the north of the bridge as memorials to unborn "water babies."
To the south, just past the Water-Splashing Jizō, is a pool where ascetic practices can be performed.
The spots borne by the fish in the river are believed to have been caused by a miracle worked by the founder of Mt. Kōya. According to the myth, a man who had caught some of these fish was cooking them over a fire. When Kūkai saw the man, he admonished him, restored the fish to life and returned them to the river, where they continue to bear the marks of the fisherman's skewers.
details.bodyTwo:
In the past, there was no bridge, so visitors were forced to purify themselves in the water of the stream. Today, it is customary instead for visitors to splash water on the fourteen statues that line the river to the right-hand side of the bridge.
The fourteen Water-Splashing Jizō take their collective name from the custom of splashing them with water.
Despite the name, not all are jizō. From left to right, we find two standing jizō, three seated jizō, a seated Dainichi Nyorai, a standing Fudō Myō'ō, five more jizō (four standing and one sitting), and finally two standing statues of Kannon.

details.headerOne: Bridge to the Most Sacred Space
details.bodyOne: The third bridge of Oku-no-in is the Gobyō-bashi, or the Bridge of the Mausoleum. It marks the entrance to the most sacred of spiritual places at Mt. Kōya. Here, visitors are expected to bow reverently before proceeding towards the place where Kōbō-daishi is enshrined. Beyond this point, men must remove their hats (if possible), and photography is forbidden.
details.bodyTwo: The bridge, though concrete, consists of thirty-six planks, one for each of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas who surround Dainichi Nyorai in the Diamond Realm Mandala. The Sanskrit letter associated with each of these beings is carved inversely on the underside of each plank. They cannot be seen from above, but, when conditions are right, they appear reflected on the surface of the river below.

details.bodyOne:
One the most striking testaments to the belief that Kūkai did not die but entered into a state of perpetual meditation is the ritual known as shōjin-gu (literally "offering to the living body"). Twice daily at 6 and 10:30 am, priests bear a small palanquin with an offering of food to the mausoleum where his body rests. Before they start the ritual procession across the Gobyō Bridge, they pause to present the food before a small shrine housing the Ajimi, or Taste Testing, Jizō.  Presumably, the bodhisattva will ensure that the meal is acceptable.
Meals are, of course, prepared in accordance with the prescriptions of shōjin-ryōri cuisine, the traditional Buddhist devotional diet observed at Mt. Kōya. However, Western foods such as pasta are occasionally included on the menu.
details.bodyTwo:
To the right of the Ajimi Jizō is a large, multi-purpose building called the Gokusho where Kūkai's meals are actually prepared. This is also where pilgrims purchase religious supplies and where they can have a ritual log of their pilgrimage stamped with the temple seal.
The building to the left of the Ajimi Jizō is the Gomadō which, among other images, contains a statue of Kūkai that he is said to have carved of himself when he was 42 years old.

details.bodyOne: In Buddhism, there are countless Buddhas. Maitraya, or Miroku in Japanese, is the Buddha of the future who currently resides in Tuṣita, the fourth of the six heavenly realms. Maitreya is expected to appear to humanity in approximately 5.6 billion years, when the teachings of the present Buddha are no longer followed. A small, unassuming shrine on the left of the path halfway between the Gobyō-bashi and the Tōrōdō marks the location where this event is believed to take place. The shrine is slightly larger than a telephone booth (if anyone remembers what those were).
details.headerTwo: Measure the Weight of your Sins
details.bodyTwo:
If you hear loud banging sounds as you approach the mausoleum of Kūkai, the source is likely to be this shrine which houses a stone the size and shape of a rugby ball. Though there are various legends concerning its origins, there is some credence to the theory that the smooth black stone is a meteorite.
The stone is placed on an interior deck of the shrine which is about waist high. To the rear is another raised platform. Visitors are invited to try lifting the stone from the lower to the upper deck using just one hand (inserted through a larger hole in the lattice). Men are supposed to use their weaker hand.
Those for whom the weight of sin is light will be able to perform the task, or so the legend has it. Give it a try but be careful as it is easy to get one's fingers pinched between the stone and the metal grate on which it sits.

details.bodyOne:
Standing before Kōbō-daishi’s mausoleum, at a spot where his earliest disciples held services after his passing, is a large building called the Tōrōdō, or "Lantern Hall." While it replaces earlier structures dating from the 11th century, the present building is from 1964. Inside, thousands of golden votive lanterns hang from the ceiling.  Additional lanterns of various sizes are arrayed in the building's basement as well as a nearby annex.
While the sections to the left and right of the Tōrōdō have altars before two of the five Wisdom Kings  (Aizen Myō'ō and Fudō Myō'ō, respectively), the altars of the central section are placed before a window that faces the mausoleum. 
Visitors who wish to get closer, must exit the Lantern Hall on the left and walk around to the back of the building.
details.headerTwo: Remaining Lit for a Thousand Years
details.bodyTwo:
While most of the hall's 25,000 lanterns are illuminated by electricity, several of the more prominent ones are oil burning lamps. 
The flames of three famous lanterns are beleived to have remained lit for nearly a thousand years. They are  displayed along the back wall at the center of the Tōrōdō. 
The Kishin-tō was purportedly first lit in the year 1016 by the holy man Jōyō (958-1047) for the salvation of his mother. Also known as Kishin Shōnin, Jōyō is credited with having helped rebuild Mt. Kōya after a series of catastrophic fires. A second lamp was donated by retired emperor Shirakawa (1053-1129) in the year 1103. 
According to a popular legend, the third lamp was the gift of a poor maiden who sold her hair to a wig maker in order to make the donation on behalf of her adoptive parents. The filial young woman's name was Oteru (which means "to shine") and her lamp is called the Hinnyo-no-ittō, or "The Poor Woman's Solitary Lamp." 
The legend tells us that when her modest donation received the mockery and contempt of a rich man who had made a more extravagant gift, a strong gust of wind immediately arose from the direction of the Inner Sanctuary. It blew out all of the wealthy man's lamps leaving Oteru's untouched.

details.bodyOne:
Another curious yet revealing object at Oku-no-in is a stone monument located on the western side of the path that runs through the modern section. Most visitors will find it on the right-hand side (across from the rocket) just before they exit into the Naka-no-hashi Parking area.
This monument is the "Shiroari kuyōtō," or Termite Memorial. Its presence and function say a lot about both Mt. Kōya and the Japanese attitude toward nature and death.
 Beneath four large hiragana that spell out the word for termite ("shiroari") is the phrase "yasuraka ni nemure," or "rest in peace."
What makes this requiem to the souls of departed termites even more remarkable is that it was erected by the Japan Termite Control Association, in other words, by the dedicated professionals who make their living by killing these wood-eating pests.
According to their website, the association established this monument in 1968 as an expression of pity for the creatures whose incompatibility with human existence resulted in the regrettable need to exterminate them.
details.bodyTwo:
Since 1972, the monument has also served as a combined memorial to people who have rendered meritorious service to the Termite Control Association. More than 120 names have been dedicated along with their insect victims.
Elsewhere at Oku-no-in, we find examples of enemies in life who now rest peacefully before the mausoleum of Kōbō-daishi. These include rival armies in recent wars as well as ancient samurai foes. The combined memorial to termites and their exterminators is consistent with this prevailing approach to life and death as witnessed here at Mt. Kōya.
